title: On your mark, get set, choose! A randomized cross-over study comparing fixed and self-selected rest periods
abstract: BACKGROUND: Studies on rest durations during high-intensity interval training (HIIT) often compare fixed and self-selected (SS) rest allocation approaches.  Frequently, the rest duration under SS conditions is unlimited, leading to  inconsistent total rest durations compared to fixed rest conditions. To address  this limitation, we recently compared fixed and SS rest conditions during cycling  HIIT sessions, while keeping the total rest duration equivalent. However, our  protocol required athletes to divide a long total rest duration (720s) across  nine intervals, which may have been overly cognitively demanding. The current  study aimed to explore the effects of the SS approach with a simplified rest  allocation task on performance, physiological, and psychological outcomes.  METHODS: Following a familiarization session, 24 professional female soccer  players completed two running HIIT sessions on a non-motorized treadmill. Each  session consisted of twelve 15s intervals, divided into three blocks, with the  goal of maximizing the distance covered. In both conditions, the between-interval  rest duration per block amounted to 270s. In the fixed condition, the rest was  uniformly allocated to 90s between each interval, whereas in the SS condition,  the athletes chose how to allocate the entirety of the 270s of rest. We compared  the following outcomes: distance, heart rate, perception of fatigue, effort,  autonomy, enjoyment, boredom, and athletes' preferences. Outcomes were compared  using aggregated measures via paired univariate tests, and across the intervals  via mixed-effects models. RESULTS: We observed comparable results in most  outcomes with the exception of higher autonomy (1-15 points) in the SS condition  (mean difference=2.1, 95%CI (0.9, 3.3) points) and a negligibly higher heart  rate in the SS condition when comparing the observations across intervals  (estimate=2.5, 95%CI (0.9, 4.2) beats X min(-1)). Additionally, participants  chose to rest for longer durations as the block progressed. Finally, the majority  of participants (65%) favored the SS condition. CONCLUSION: This study further  solidifies that SS and fixed approaches with matched total rest durations result  in similar performance, physiological, and psychological responses. This effect  persists even when the total rest duration required to be allocated is relatively  short. Therefore, coaches and trainees can choose either approach based on their  preferences and training goals.
keyFindings: Self-selected and fixed rest approaches with matched total rest durations result in similar performance

title: Head-torso coordination in police officers wearing loaded tactical vests during running
abstract: Background: The influence of load carriage in operational police officers is not well understood despite a relatively high injury rate. Assessing load related changes in head and torso coordination may provide valuable insight into plausible injury mechanisms. Research question: Do typical police tactical vest loads alter head and torso coordination during running?  Methods: Thirty-eight UK police officers ran at a self-selected pace (>2 ms 1) on a non-motorised treadmill in four vest load conditions (unloaded, and low, high and evenly distributed loads). Peak head and torso tilt, and peak vest displacement were compared between all four conditions. Timings between vest and torso change of direction were compared between the three loaded conditions. The coupling angle between the head and torso calculated using modified vector coding were compared between unloaded and each loaded conditions using Statistical Parametric Mapping. Results: No significant differences were found between conditions for peak head or torso tilt alone (p > 0.05). Loading equipment low on the vest led to significantly greater mediolateral vest displacements (38 mm) away from the torso than a high (34 mm) or evenly distributed (30 mm) conditions. The vest was found to change direction vertically before the torso in the anterior-posterior direction, and then influence torso motion. The loaded conditions changed the head-torso coupling from in-phase (with head-dominancy) to anti-phase (with torso dominancy) between 55% and 77% stance. Anti-phase with a relatively stationary head and the torso rotating forward likely places a greater concentric demand on the posterior neck muscles relative to unloaded running. Significance: Current tactical vest designs allow significant extra displacement of load away from the body during running, altering coordination at the head and torso. N = 38 (24 males (M); age (years) M 44 ± 7, F 40 ± 9)
keyFindings: Loading equipment low on vest led to greater mediolateral vest displacements; altered head-torso coupling

title: Maintaining Cognitive Performance at the Expense of Gait Speed for Asymptomatic Concussed Athletes
abstract: Our goal was to evaluate persisting deficits in gait and executive functioning in asymptomatic athletes with a history of concussion using a novel approach combining a dual-task paradigm and post-exercise exertion. Thirty-eight athletes aged 17 to 25 years old participated in the study, including 18 with a history of concussion. The dual-task paradigm required walking continuously at a predetermined self-paced target speed of 6.5 km/h while executing a complex switch task. Athletes completed two conditions, each on separate days: (1) dual task alone and (2) dual task following 20 min of running on a non-motorized treadmill. The statistical analyses revealed a significant reduction in gait speed exclusively for athletes with a history of concussion and only following the post-exercise condition (p = 0.008). These findings suggest that although asymptomatic concussed athletes maintain a cognitive performance comparable to non-concussed athletes, this appears to be achieved at the expense of gait speed. Our results underscore the importance of incorporating gait assessments and post-exercise exertion into concussion evaluation protocols in both research and clinical settings.
keyFindings: Asymptomatic concussed athletes showed reduced gait speed following post-exercise condition while maintaining cognitive performance

title: A non-motorized treadmill validated for the traditional overground 6-min walk test
abstract: BACKGROUND: The six-minute walk test (6MWT) is a commonly used clinical and research test to assess aerobic capacity. However, in many settings, the 30-m corridor required to conduct the test may not be available. Evaluation of the use of a non-motorized treadmill as an alternative method has not been well studied. PURPOSE: This study compared the distances walked during the traditional (TRAD) 6MWT on a flat indoor surface to a non-motorized treadmill (NMT) to validate the use of the NMT as an alternative testing method. METHODS: A total of 55 healthy adults (28 females) completed the TRAD 6MWT and NMT 6MWT during the same testing session (randomized order). The levels of agreement between the two methods were quantified using Lin's concordance correlation coefficients. Additionally, a multiple linear regression was developed to predict TRAD 6MWT distance with covariates age, sex, and body mass index (BMI) from NMT distance walked. RESULTS: The average TRAD distance walked was 630 m and the average NMT distance walked was 607 m. The mean difference of 23 m between the two methods was nonsignificant. There was good agreement between methods (rc = 0.84) showing no differences. A multiple linear regression was developed and revealed that NMT distance significantly predicted TRAD distance when controlling for age, sex, height, and weight (Standardized Beta = 0.791, p < 0.001). CONCLUSION: The use of the NMT for 6MWT was deemed a valid and feasible replacement for the TRAD 6MWT based on the results of this study. N=55 ± 15 (28 Females). Presentation: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Md1_zvpPsTc
keyFindings: Non-motorized treadmill deemed valid and feasible replacement for traditional 6MWT

title: Application of synchronous music reinforcement to increase walking speed: A novel approach for training intensity
journal: Journal of the Experimental Analysis of Behavior
abstract: Walking is a common and preferred form of exercise. Although there are current recommendations for walking volume (e.g., steps per day), recent research has begun to distinguish volume from intensity (e.g., “brisk” walking) as an important dimension of exercise. Increasing intensity may confer health advantages beyond volume measures because it shifts cardiovascular performance to more vigorous training zones. Reinforcement-based approaches have been valuable in increasing volume measures of exercise, and the present study sought to develop a corresponding reinforcement approach to training walking intensity. For this study, we used a continuous reinforcement paradigm where music played only while walking met specified criteria; otherwise, music playback stopped. As a result, music was synchronized with walking performance. Seventeen participants walked on a nonmotorized treadmill at a self-selected pace. Across the session, different conditions arranged for music to play independent of walking speed or contingent on speed increases or decreases. An extinction component assessed performance when music was withdrawn completely. Walking speed was selectively increased and decreased by adjusting the contingencies that were arranged for music, and variability in speed increased during extinction, with both findings indicating that music was a reinforcer. Heart rate was also increased to moderate-vigorous intensities during reinforcement. The findings provide a compelling case that walking intensity can be modified by music reinforcement. We suggest that synchronous schedules may be an important foundation for future exercise technologies that are based on reinforcement. N=17 Women (mean age = 22)
keyFindings: Walking speed selectively increased and decreased by adjusting contingencies for music reinforcement; Rotary encoder was used to measure speed

title: Curved non-motorized treadmills do not biomechanically replicate overground running better than motorized treadmills
abstract: The purpose of this study was to determine if curved non-motorized treadmills can reproduce overground running better than motorized treadmills by analysing the differences in joint kinematics (hip, knee, and ankle) using SPM. Nineteen recreational runners completed three randomized running tests on these surfaces. Kinematic data from the hip, knee, and ankle joints were collected. Two-tailed SPM t-tests were performed to analyse time-continuous gait cycles in three anatomical planes of each joint. Higher within-subject variability was observed in the frontal and transverse planes during curved non-motorized treadmill running. SPM analysis showed more significant differences (p < 0.05) between curved nonmotorized treadmill and overground than between motorized treadmill and overground, mainly in knee (from 12% to 30% and 93% to 99% of the gait cycle) and ankle (from 19% to 23% of the gait cycle) in the sagittal plane. Therefore, running on curved non-motorized treadmills is more biomechanically different compared to overground than motorized treadmills, and might not be the best strategy to replicate overground running in terms of joint kinematics during highly controlled research studies. However, they could be an interesting tool in rehabilitation or training environments since the changes observed in joint kinematics were likely not functionally relevant. N=19 (mean age = 36 ± 9)
keyFindings: Curved non-motorized treadmills are more biomechanically different from overground than motorized treadmills

title: Influence of surface condition and prolonged running on impact accelerations
abstract: Compared running surface effects on impact accelerations during 30-minute runs. 21 recreational runners completed tests on MT, cNMT, and overground.
keyFindings: Reduction in impact accelerations on cNMT; increased stride frequency and higher RPE and heart rate

title: A commentary on soccer match-play simulations for applied research and practice
abstract: Review of soccer simulations for research and training. Scored free-running, non-motorised, and motorised-treadmill simulations for research and practical applications.
keyFindings: Commentary reviewing soccer match-play simulations including non-motorised treadmill-based designs

title: Running Mechanics After Repeated Sprints in Femoroacetabular Impingement Syndrome
abstract: 49 recreationally active individuals with FAIS, cam morphology, or healthy controls measured before and after repeated sprint exercise on nonmotorized treadmill.
keyFindings: Changes in running biomechanics after repeated sprints did not differ between FAIS and controls

title: Validity of Inertial Measurement Units to Measure Lower-Limb Kinematics and Pelvic Orientation at Submaximal and Maximal Effort Running Speeds
abstract: 20 participants ran at 70%, 80%, 90%, and 100% maximal effort on curved non-motorized treadmill. Assessed IMU accuracy for measuring sagittal plane lower-limb kinematics and pelvic orientation.
keyFindings: IMU system effective for measuring lower-limb kinematics during sprinting; pelvic orientation estimation less accurate

title: Time of Day Effects on Anaerobic Performance Using a Nonmotorized Treadmill
journal: Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research
abstract: 26 recreationally active adults completed 30nmt at 9am, 2pm, and 7pm in randomized order. No significant main effects for time found for peak power, mean power, peak velocity, mean velocity, or distance.
keyFindings: No significant differences in performance during maximal anaerobic assessments throughout day; peak/nadir times may be individualized

title: Treadmill and Running Speed Effects on Acceleration Impacts: Curved Non-Motorized vs Motorized Treadmill
journal: International Journal of Environmental Research and Public Health
abstract: 27 recreational runners ran at different speeds on cNMT and MT. Analysis showed lower impact accelerations but higher intensity training on cNMT.
keyFindings: Reduction in impact accelerations on cNMT; higher heart rate and RPE on cNMT

title: Repeated sprints alter mechanical work done by hip and knee, but not ankle, sagittal moments
journal: Journal of Science and Medicine in Sport
abstract: 18 recreational athletes performed 12 maximal 30-m sprints on non-motorised treadmill with 3D kinematics and GRF recorded during overground sprint before and after.
keyFindings: Reductions in mechanical work by hip and knee joints during maximal sprinting after repeated running protocol

title: Application of Wind Tunnel Device for Evaluation of Biokinetic Parameters of Running
abstract: Study in Planica Nordic Centre wind tunnel with AirRunner treadmill equipped with force sensors. Examined running under conditions of headwind and backwind at different speeds.
keyFindings: Wind tunnel and treadmill sufficiently accurate to perform kinetic measurements of running parameters in changing conditions

title: In-Season Repeated-Sprint Training in Hypoxia in International Field Hockey Players
journal: Frontiers in Sports and Active Living
abstract: 11 elite male field hockey players completed 8 multi-set RSH sessions on non-motorized treadmill in normobaric hypoxic chamber over 6 weeks.
keyFindings: 6-week in-season RSH program improved average and peak repeated treadmill sprint speeds following eight sessions

title: Virtual Reality Gait Training to Promote Balance and Gait Among Older People: A Randomized Clinical Trial
abstract: 56 elderly individuals completed VR gait training with non-motorized treadmill for 50 min/day, 5 days/week for 4 weeks. Significant improvements in balance and gait spatiotemporal parameters.
keyFindings: Virtual reality gait training with non-motorized treadmill improved balance and gait ability in elderly with fall history

title: Muscle Damage and Metabolic Responses to Repeated-Sprint Running With and Without Deceleration
journal: Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research
abstract: 14 male team-sport athletes performed repeated-sprint running protocols on nonmotorized treadmill with and without deceleration. No significant differences in measured variables between conditions.
keyFindings: Removal of deceleration from repeated-sprint running had no effect on metabolism, performance, or markers of muscle damage

title: Time-of-day variation on performance measures in repeated-sprint tests: a systematic review
abstract: Systematic review of time-of-day effects on repeated sprint performance. 10 articles included. Eight studies found repeated-sprint performance increased in favor of evening.
keyFindings: Repeated-sprint performance affected by time-of-day with greater performance in late/early afternoon

title: Physiological and Perceptual Demands of Running on a Curved Nonmotorized Treadmill Compared With Running on a Motorized Treadmill Set at Different Grades
journal: Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research
abstract: 10 male team-sport athletes ran at 2.78 m/s on cNMT and MT at different grades (4%, 6%, 8%). Curved design of cNMT estimated to mimic 6.9±3% MT grade.
keyFindings: VO2 and RPE responses on cNMT similar to 6-8% MT grade at matched running velocities

title: Comparison of a Traditional Graded Exercise Protocol With a Self-Paced 1-km Test to Assess Maximal Oxygen Consumption
journal: International Journal of Sports Physiology and Performance
abstract: 24 sport-science students performed traditional GXT on motorized treadmill and 1-km self-paced running test on nonmotorized treadmill to compare VO2max assessment methods.
keyFindings: Higher VO2max values observed in 1-km self-paced test than in traditional GXT (53.2 vs 51.8 ml/kg/min); difference only present in men

title: Measuring the response to simulated fixture congestion in soccer
abstract: 11 male team-sport athletes completed two self-paced simulations 72-h apart on non-motorized treadmill. Assessed within- and post-match responses including voluntary activation and physiological markers.
keyFindings: 72-h recovery sufficient to maintain activity between simulations; lower-body strength and aerobic capacity displayed protective effects

title: Metabolic and kinematic responses while walking and running on motorised and curved non-motorised treadmill
abstract: Assessed metabolic and kinematic parameters during walking and incremental running on motorised and curved non-motorised treadmills in 25 volunteers.
keyFindings: Energy cost of walking and running were 37% and 17% greater on CNMT than MT respectively

title: Greater loss of horizontal force after a repeated-sprint test in footballers with a previous hamstring injury
journal: Journal of Science and Medicine in Sport
abstract: 40 Western Australia State League footballers (20 with previous unilateral hamstring injury) completed 10×6-s repeated-sprint test on non-motorised treadmill dynamometer. Mean horizontal force production 13% lower in previously injured leg.
keyFindings: Greater fatigued-induced change in mean horizontal force in legs with previous hamstring injury

title: The Effects of Inhaled Terbutaline on 3-km Running Time-Trial Performance
journal: International Journal of Sports Physiology and Performance
abstract: 16 participants completed 3-km running time trials on nonmotorized treadmill following placebo and 2mg and 4mg inhaled terbutaline doses.
keyFindings: Therapeutic dosing of terbutaline does not improve 3-km running performance despite significantly increased FEV1

title: Repeated Treadmill Sprints Impair Cognitive Performance in Amateur Team-Sport Athletes When Performed in Normobaric Hypoxia
abstract: 11 amateur team-sport athletes performed RSR444 under normoxic and hypoxic conditions on non-motorized treadmill. Cognitive function tests performed pre and 20 min post.
keyFindings: Single bout of RSH with 14.5% O2 resulted in impaired cognitive function in amateur team-sport athletes

title: The effects of recovery duration on physiological and perceptual responses of trained runners during four self-paced HIIT sessions
journal: Journal of Science and Medicine in Sport
abstract: 12 trained runners performed HIIT session of six 4-min work intervals on non-motorized treadmill with recovery durations of 1MIN, 2MIN, 3MIN, or self-selected duration.
keyFindings: Recovery duration length had limited effect on physiological strain; running velocities higher with longest recovery (3MIN)

title: Independent or simultaneous lowering of core and skin temperature has no impact on self-paced intermittent running performance in hot conditions
abstract: To investigate effects of lowering core and mean skin temperature on self-paced intermittent running in heat. 10 males completed four randomised 46-min self-paced intermittent protocols on non-motorised treadmill.
keyFindings: Lowering core and skin temperature had no impact on self-paced intermittent running performance in the heat

title: A comparison of physiological demand between self-propelled and motorized treadmill exercise
journal: International Journal of Physical Education, Fitness and Sports
abstract: Twenty subjects performed 3km runs on self-propelled (Woodway Curve 3.0) and motorized treadmills. Self-propelled treadmill elicited greater physiological response.
keyFindings: VO2 was significantly greater on self-propelled treadmill (44.90 vs 34.38 ml/kg/min)

title: A comparison of both motorized and nonmotorized treadmill gait kinematics to overground locomotion
abstract: 20 healthy adults performed walking and running overground and on MT and NMT. Analyzed shoulder, trunk, and lower-extremity kinematics for each condition.
keyFindings: MT matched overground kinematics; NMT showed increased flexions in late swing and early stance

title: The Effect of a Curved Non-Motorized Treadmill on Running Gait Length, Imbalance and Stride Angle
abstract: 16 college-aged participants completed 5 four-minute running bouts alternating between TMT and CNT. Gait analyzed using Optogait equipment.
keyFindings: Running on CNT resulted in significant changes in gait characteristics (step length, stride length, imbalance, stride angle)

title: The physiological and perceptual demands of running on a curved non-motorised treadmill: Implications for self-paced training
journal: Journal of Science and Medicine in Sport
abstract: 13 trained male runners performed incremental running test on MT then ran at progressively higher velocities on cNMT and MT. cNMT elicited higher relative oxygen uptake across all velocities.
keyFindings: Running on cNMT has higher physiological and perceptual demands; 90% VO2max achieved at 62% Vmax on cNMT vs 81% Vmax on MT

title: Self-Paced Team-Sport Match Simulation Results in Reductions in Voluntary Activation and Modifications to Biological, Perceptual, and Performance Measures
journal: Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research
abstract: 12 male team-sport athletes performed 90-minute self-paced soccer match simulation on nonmotorized treadmill. Assessments at prematch, halftime, postmatch, and recovery timepoints.
keyFindings: Half-time reductions in voluntary activation and potentiated twitch plateaued by postmatch; perceptual and neuromuscular responses related to running intensity

title: Comparison of Long and Short High-Intensity Interval Exercise Bouts on Running Performance, Physiological and Perceptual Responses
abstract: 12 healthy students performed long (4×4 min) and short intervals (4×8×20 s) of high-intensity training on non-motorized treadmill with same total duration.
keyFindings: Short intervals perceived easier than long intervals even though cardiovascular and metabolic responses similar; EPOC lasted significantly longer after short intervals

title: Five-Kilometer Time Trial Reliability of a Nonmotorized Treadmill and Comparison of Physiological and Perceptual Responses vs. a Motorized Treadmill
journal: Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research
abstract: 10 male runners completed 3 TT to establish reliability then ran at 5-km pace on NMT and MT. Familiarization session should be included for TT using NMT.
keyFindings: ICC improved between TT2 and TT3 (0.99); NMT resulted in 24% slower pace but similar VO2, RER, lactate, and HR responses

title: Non-motorized treadmill running is associated with higher cardiometabolic demands
abstract: 14 trained runners performed 5×6-min bouts at progressively higher speeds. Running on cNMT showed higher cardiometabolic demand than overground or motorized treadmill.
keyFindings: cNMT required 22% higher VO2max than overground and 16% higher than motorized treadmill

title: Comparison of dynamic stability during walking and running on nonmotorized curved treadmill according to curvature radius
journal: Journal of Mechanics in Medicine and Biology
abstract: 16 healthy adult men maintained different self-paced speeds on NMCT with three curvature radii. Dynamic stability assessed across speeds and radii.
keyFindings: Stability decreased at slow speeds but increased at fast speeds as curvature radius decreased

title: Dynamic Stability on Nonmotorized Curved Treadmill: Self-Paced Speed versus Fixed Speed
journal: International Journal of Precision Engineering and Manufacturing
abstract: Compared margin of stability under self-paced and fixed-speed conditions using nonmotorized curved treadmill with different curvature radii.
keyFindings: Self-paced and fixed-speed conditions at different curvature radii influence dynamic stability

title: Prediction of Belt Sag on a Non-Motorized Curved Treadmill
journal: International Journal of Precision Engineering and Manufacturing
abstract: This study suggests a design method for curved treadmill with mathematical model that enables prediction of belt sag extent. An experimental belt system was produced and measured values confirmed validity of the mathematical model.
keyFindings: Mathematical model enables prediction of upper and lower belt sags according to design factors

title: The effect of 400 µg inhaled salbutamol on 3 km time trial performance in a low humidity environment
abstract: 14 participants (7 EVH+ve, 7 EVH-ve) performed 3 km running time-trials on non-motorized treadmill 15 minutes following inhalation of salbutamol, placebo, or control.
keyFindings: 400µg inhaled salbutamol does not improve 3 km time-trial performance despite significantly increased HR and FEV1

title: CI2 for creating and comparing confidence-intervals for time-series bivariate plots
abstract: Developed CI2 method to calculate confidence-intervals on time-series bivariate plots. Test data were knee and ankle angles from 10 participants running on motorised and curved non-motorised treadmills.
keyFindings: CI2 method provides effective quantification of CI for bivariate plots and exploration of differences between time-series

title: Acute effects of psychological relaxation techniques between two physical tasks
abstract: 27 sport science students tested repeated sprint ability twice during day with 25-min breaks including different relaxation interventions. Tests executed on non-motorised treadmill (6 sprints of 4s).
keyFindings: Systematic breathing led to better repeated sprint performance compared to control sessions

title: Running performance in the heat is improved by similar magnitude with pre-exercise cold-water immersion and mid-exercise facial water spray
abstract: 9 trained male runners completed 5 km time trials in heat with pre-cooling by cold-water immersion, mid-exercise cooling by facial water spray, or no cooling control.
keyFindings: Both pre-exercise cold-water immersion and mid-exercise facial water spray improved 5 km performance by similar magnitude

title: A comparison of mixed-method cooling interventions on preloaded running performance in the heat
journal: Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research
abstract: 11 trained runners completed preloaded running time trials (20 min at 70% VO2max and 3 km time trial) with precooling, midcooling, combination of all methods, or control in heat.
keyFindings: Performance improved with midcooling, whereas precooling had little or no influence

title: Effects of Short or Long Warm-up on Intermediate Running Performance
journal: Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research
abstract: 13 experienced endurance-trained athletes conducted 2 types of warm-ups (long: general + specific; short: specific only) followed by 3-minute running test on nonmotorized treadmill.
keyFindings: Short warm-up as effective as long warm-up for intermediate performance; no significant differences in running performance variables

title: Reduced vertical displacement of the center of mass is not accompanied by reduced oxygen uptake during walking
abstract: Investigated effect of reduced vertical displacement of CoM on oxygen uptake and walking economy without imposing altered gait patterns by having subjects walk on curved treadmill and flat treadmill.
keyFindings: Reduced vertical displacement of CoM on curved treadmill accompanied by increase in oxygen uptake and walking economy

title: Physical and psychomotor performance of Australian football and rugby league officials during match simulation
abstract: 12 elite officials completed match simulation on non-motorised treadmill examining psychomotor performance changes during laboratory-based match simulation.
keyFindings: Response time improved when running above 65% maximal sprinting speed during intermittent exercise

title: Improved end-stage high-intensity performance but similar glycemic responses after waxy barley starch vs dextrose in Type 1 diabetes
journal: The Journal of Sports Medicine and Physical Fitness
abstract: 7 T1DM participants consumed waxy barley starch or dextrose before sub-maximal exercise followed by 10-min performance run on non-motorized treadmill.
keyFindings: Waxy barley starch showed improved end-stage high-intensity performance compared to dextrose in T1DM

title: Comparison of VO2peak performance on a motorized vs. a nonmotorized treadmill
journal: Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research
abstract: 24 volunteers performed 2 peak GXT sessions (1 MT and 1 NMT). Neither peak VO2, peak HR, nor VT were significantly different, but submaximal responses differed.
keyFindings: Peak values similar between NMT and MT; majority of submaximal data significantly different between trials

title: Running performance and thermal sensation in the heat are improved with menthol mouth rinse but not ice slurry ingestion
journal: Scandinavian Journal of Medicine & Science in Sports
abstract: 11 moderately trained male runners completed 5-km time trials in hot conditions with ice slurry ingestion, menthol mouth rinse, or no intervention on non-motorized treadmill.
keyFindings: Menthol mouth rinse improved running performance in heat; ice slurry reduced core temperature but did not improve performance

title: Comparison of perceptual and physiological variables of running on a track, motorized treadmill, and non-motorized curved treadmill at increasing velocity
abstract: The aim of this study was to compare perceptual and physiological variables between running on three different modalities at increasing velocity. Ten male athletes conducted three 1000 m laps at increasing velocity on three different running modalities.
keyFindings: Physiological and perceptual variables were higher on non-motorized curved treadmill compared to track or motorized treadmill

title: Asymmetry after hamstring injury in english premier league: issue resolved, or perhaps not?
abstract: Assessed horizontal force deficits during maximum sprint running on non-motorized treadmill in Premier League football players with previous hamstring strains.
keyFindings: No significant differences in peak forces between previously injured and non-injured limbs

title: Automated gait temporal-spatial assessment from non-motorized treadmill belt speed data
abstract: Determined validity of automated technique using belt speed data from NMT to estimate temporal-spatial gait parameters in 17 injury-free adults.
keyFindings: Belt speed data from NMT can predict gait events and analyze gait metrics with high accuracy

title: Sprinting performance on the Woodway Curve 3.0 is related to muscle architecture
abstract: 28 healthy adults completed 30-s maximal sprint on Woodway Curve 3.0. Muscle thickness, CSA, and echo intensity of rectus femoris and vastus lateralis measured via ultrasound.
keyFindings: Muscle architecture is related to and predictive of treadmill sprinting performance

title: A Clustered Repeated-Sprint Running Protocol for Team-Sport Athletes Performed in Normobaric Hypoxia
abstract: 10 amateur team-sport athletes completed RSR444 protocol (4 sets of 4, 4-s sprints) in normoxia and hypoxia on non-motorized treadmill. Performance maintained in normoxia but not hypoxia.
keyFindings: Amateur team-sport athletes unable to maintain performance in hypoxic conditions during RSR444 protocol

title: Increased physiologic intensity during walking and running on a non-motorized, curved treadmill
abstract: 10 healthy athletic adults walked and ran on NMCT and SMT at matched speeds. Intensity significantly greater for NMCT: Walking 5.9 vs 3.4 METs; Running 10.7 vs 7.3 METs.
keyFindings: NMCT elicits greater physiological stimulus than SMT with small but significant changes in RPE at matched speeds

title: The Reliability of Running Performance in a 5 km Time Trial on a Non-motorized Treadmill
abstract: 17 male runners performed familiarization then 2 separate maximal 5 km running time trials on non-motorized treadmill. Most physiological responses demonstrated good reliability.
keyFindings: Performance time in 5 km running time trial on non-motorized treadmill is highly reliable (CV: 1.2%, ICC: 0.99)

title: The validity of endurance running performance on the Curve 3TM non-motorised treadmill
abstract: 10 male runners performed randomised 5-km time trials on NMT and outdoor athletics track. Strong correlations suggest NMT is valid tool for assessment of endurance running performance.
keyFindings: Performance time strongly correlated between NMT and overground (r=0.82); runners consistently slower on NMT

title: A self-paced intermittent protocol on a non-motorised treadmill: a reliable alternative to assessing team-sport running performance
abstract: 10 male team-sport athletes attended 5 sessions performing 30-min self-paced protocol on Woodway Curve 3.0. Peak/mean speed and distance variables exhibited CV <5%.
keyFindings: Self-paced team-sport running protocol on NMT produces reliable speed/distance and power data after single familiarization

title: Placebo Effect: Influence on Repeated Intermittent Sprint Performance on Consecutive Days
journal: Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research
abstract: 10 subjects performed 4 repeated sprint tests under control or placebo beverage conditions separated by 24 hours on nonmotorized treadmill. Placebo trial produced significantly higher peak and mean power.
keyFindings: Placebo administration can attenuate decline in performance as fatigue increases during repeated sprinting bouts

title: The effect of beetroot juice on repeated sprint performance and muscle force production
abstract: Examined effects of beetroot juice on muscle force production and repeated sprint performance using isokinetic dynamometer and non-motorized treadmill.
keyFindings: No differences between trials for muscle strength measurement with beetroot juice supplementation

title: Power, fatigue, and recovery changes in NCAA Division I hockey players across a competitive season
journal: Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research
abstract: 20 NCAA Division I men's hockey athletes performed repeated sprint tests pre- and postseason. Mean power was significantly higher in preseason vs postseason performance.
keyFindings: Athletes unable to maintain power during repeated sprint work postseason; increased perceptual strain observed

title: Speed, Force, and Power Values Produced From Nonmotorized Treadmill Test Are Related to Sprinting Performance
journal: Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research
abstract: 78 physically active adults performed 30-second maximal sprint on curved nonmotorized treadmill. Strong relationships found between 30-m sprint time and treadmill performance variables.
keyFindings: Sprinting performance on nonmotorized treadmill significantly predicts short-distance sprint time

title: Repeated sprint training in normobaric hypoxia
abstract: 30 male rugby players completed 12 repeated sprint training sessions in hypoxia or normoxia on non-motorised treadmill over 4 weeks.
keyFindings: Hypoxic RS training resulted in twofold greater improvements than normoxic training

title: Reliability of the Woodway Curve non-motorized treadmill for assessing anaerobic performance
abstract: 32 recreationally active adults performed familiarization and experimental trials on Woodway Curve 3.0 and Wingate test. High reliability observed after 2 familiarization trials.
keyFindings: Curved treadmill provides reliable sprint test after two familiarization trials; strong relationships with cycle ergometer

title: Estimated V(O2)max from the rockport walk test on a nonmotorized curved treadmill
journal: Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research
abstract: 23 healthy adults performed Rockport Walk Test on measured indoor track and on curved treadmill. All VO2max estimations different from observed except for one equation on track.
keyFindings: RWTC underestimates VO2max but may be beneficial if new equation created specifically for curved treadmill

title: High-intensity re-warm-ups enhance soccer performance
abstract: Participants performed 2×26-min periods of intermittent activity protocol on non-motorized treadmill, interspersed by 15-min passive recovery, 3-min small-sided game, or 5RM leg-press. Various performance measures assessed.
keyFindings: 5RM leg-press re-warm-up improved physical performance; small-sided game re-warm-up enhanced skill execution

title: Isomaltulose improves glycemia and maintains run performance in type 1 diabetes
journal: Medicine and Science in Sports and Exercise
abstract: Seven T1DM individuals consumed isomaltulose or dextrose before incremental run followed by 10-min all-out performance test on nonmotorized treadmill.
keyFindings: Isomaltulose improves blood glucose responses and produces similar high-intensity run performance vs dextrose

title: Effects of Motorized vs Non-Motorized Treadmill Training on Hamstring/Quadriceps Strength Ratios
abstract: Examined effects of 4 weeks training on motorized vs non-motorized treadmills on hamstring/quadriceps strength ratios in 31 subjects.
keyFindings: Training mode elicited specific changes in concentric strength; no effect on eccentric hamstrings

title: Energy expenditure while walking on a non-motorized treadmill
journal: Journal of Strength and Conditioning Research
abstract: Study examined energy expenditure while walking on a non-motorized treadmill to assess metabolic demands.
keyFindings: Energy expenditure measured during walking on non-motorized treadmill
